SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Miss Mollie P. Jones

2. Your address: 2259 Albert Street, Regina, Sask.

3. Date: March 5th, 1903

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Marshall, Saline Co., Mo., U.S.A.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: John E. Aldridge, Implement Dealer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): Early fall of 1903

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: Butte, Overhedge and Whitehall, Montana.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 3 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West?: E.C. Jones, my husband's father, filled on a homestead for us.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?): Through E.C. Jones and family.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Mrs. Mollie P. Jones
2. Your address: 2259 Albert Street, Regina, Sask.
3. Date: March 5th, 1908
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you were under 18 years of age.)
9. That were your reasons for coming here?
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

E.C. Jones, my husband's father, filled out the home sheet for us.

Other E.C. from our family.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
My father & mother came with us.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
My family came here by covered wagon.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
Covered wagon and demovolt - horses.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.).

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
In home of E.C. Jones

16. Where did you settle or take up land? S.E. 4 of 12-14-20-W2

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
Opportunity, Washi Kec., 1918 - March 1931

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
Small hardware and tin smith shop.
On farm
Jones, Mrs. Mollie P.
2299 Albert Street,
Regina, Sask.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
My family came here by casual wagon.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a family?
My brother & mother came with me.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
Crowd wagons and driving horses.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, etc.)
Meeting with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents, etc.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
The home of E. G. Jones

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
88.47 acres - 12-14-20-11/2

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
Opportunity Wells, Nov. 1918 - March 1931

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
Small business and farming.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Frequently

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Horace P. Jones and married at Butte, Mont., Sept. 26, 1899

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Not to my knowledge

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My parents, J. T. and M. E. Allredge came with us and homesteaded on the N.W. 4 of 12-14-20-W.R.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

During the winter months we traveled in a cutter or dog sleigh. Summer months we used the buggy. Visited friends often; Methodist Church service in Buck Lake Church; Christian Church services in our home stead house. The early Methodist ministers often guests in our home, I think especially of Mr. Ball and Mr. Cameron. Mr. Ball played the violin but when sickness came unexpectedly he could put on an apron and perform a meal.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone come to Salt Lake City? If so, who and when?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell where they came from and where they settled.

My brothers, J. H. and M. E., all came from

Scottish, Ill., and came to St. George on the N.W.T.

of 18-14-20-00 P.M.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Bought a Buick; steering wheel on right-hand side of car

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Wilson, times

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   The car often took me to Regina

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Almost weekly

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   Went there

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period:
   My mail order catalogue was usually for clothing, toys for the children

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Staying permanently
25. When was the first car used in the community?

26. If you owned a car before 1914, then did you use it? Yes/No

27. What was your trading center? How far from your home? Wilby, Iowa

28. Did you continue to travel there? (Indicate any changes due to new transportation, better roads, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Almost weekly.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. Then (or ever) did you begin to buy through the mail order catalogue?

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out when did you make this decision?

My mail order catalogue was actually for clothing, toys for the children.

Staying permanently
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My husband, president of Wilcox rural telephone Co., I was Sec'y for Yankee Ridge School district for several years. I was President of the "Sun Shirt" Club also. President of Yankee Ridge Community Club.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

When our school district was formed it was named "Yankee Ridge" because the settlers were almost all from the States. The school is still the Yankee Ridge school on the N.W. corner of our farm.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My husband was president of Wilcox rural telephone co., I was secy for Yankee Ridge School district for several years. I was President of the "Sunshine" Club also President of Yankee Ridge Community Club.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

When our school district was formed it was named "Yankee Ridge" because the settlers were almost all from the States. The school is still the Yankee Ridge School on the N.W. corner of our farm.

Reginald T. Jones, Colfax, Washington, sells International farm machinery, trucks etc.
